instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1932: What is A1932? A1932 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Late 2018, 2019 with EMC 3184, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01521..
definitions.820-01521: What is 820-01521? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Powers/Boots from rear (XB) port but cycles from front port (XA)
threads.message:
System reportedly just quit on the user one day and wouldn't turn back on.  No signs of liquid exposure.

This board has been picked up and put down over the course of a few weeks now.  At this point I honestly am not sure what I did to it - there was <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> reflowing and touchups, etc involved. - but the last thing that I did was remove and reball the top (XB / master) <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>.  Before that the system was sitting at 5v / 0.24A from all ports.  This last reball was in response to the top port only receiving any power in one orientation, which was an issue I later realized may have only been due to a faulty "new" USB-C portset.  :|  

Amateur hour over here like woah.  

Anyway, right now where I'm at is that the system will power and boot all the way into the OS from the top port, but the bottom port is cycling.

Nothing else looks out of place, so... just replace the bottom <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> now too or is there some TBT ROM stuff I should be looking into?

Also what lines of communication are used for the slave <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> to talk to the TBT ROM through the master <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>?  I'd love to know.

Thank you!

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Powers/Boots from rear (XB) port but cycles from front port (XA)
threads.message:
Rear port (<CHIP>U3200</CHIP>) boots first, being directly connected to TBT ROM.
Then share the info to front port (<CHIP>U3100</CHIP>) through <SIGNAL>UPC_XA_UART_TX</SIGNAL>/RX lines.

Compare diode mode readings around Q/<CHIP>U3100</CHIP> with the other channel.
You can try changing <TRANSISTOR>Q3100</TRANSISTOR> first.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Powers/Boots from rear (XB) port but cycles from front port (XA)
threads.message:
REPORTING BACK!

Yeah, obviously it was the <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>.  

<CHIP>U3200</CHIP> was fully functional. <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> was the problem <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> all along and the replacement I installed originally must have just been bad. 

The new CD3215s showed up and everything was 100% golden after the first replacement attempt.

Thank you!
